title: R45696
content: This report analyzes forest management provisions in the 115th Congress compared to prior laws. Enacted through two legislative vehicles, the Stephen Sepp Wildfire Suppression Funding and Forest Management Activities Act and the Agricultural Improvement Act of 2018, both laws address forest management from three perspectives. The 2018 farm bill, signed into law on December 20, 2018, included provisions for forest management on federal lands. This report focuses on the changes to Forest Service management of federal forests. The 2018 farm bill included provisions for forest management on federal lands, focusing on changes to Forest Service and Bureau of Land Management management of their respective lands. The report provides background information on the National Forest System and BLM's public lands, as well as an overview of laws such as the National Environmental Policy Act and the Healthy Forests Restoration Act. The report discusses the management of federal lands by the Forest Service and Bureau of Land Management, covering laws like the National Environmental Policy Act and the Healthy Forests Restoration Act. It also analyzes provisions enacted by the 115th Congress affecting forest management activities and procedural requirements. The report summarizes provisions enacted by the 115th Congress affecting project planning, wildland fire management, forest management, and restoration programs for federal lands managed by the Forest Service and Bureau of Land Management. It discusses relevant issues, changes made in the 115th Congress, and potential issues for Congress in each category. The report broadly discusses relevant issues, summarizes changes made in the 115th Congress related to forest management, and highlights potential issues for Congress. It includes in-depth coverage of some provisions, reflecting the complexity of the issue and congressional interest. The Appendix contains side-by-side tables comparing forest-related provisions in each law to prior law.
